article.title: The Gaia-ESO Survey: Dynamical models of flattened, rotating globular clusters

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows rotation curves for two globular clusters. What information does a rotation curve provide?
choices: The relationship between the distance from the cluster center and the cluster\'s mass.
The change in the average line-of-sight velocity of stars as a function of their distance from the rotation axis.
The distribution of stellar ages within the cluster.
The variation in the cluster\'s luminosity as a function of distance from its center.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main advantage of using the Modified Plummer model (solid black lines) over the traditional Plummer model (dashed black lines) to fit the surface density profiles of some globular clusters?
choices: The Modified Plummer model better captures the slower turnover in the density profile of younger clusters.
The Modified Plummer model accounts for the presence of dark matter in globular clusters.
The Modified Plummer model is computationally less expensive to implement.
The Modified Plummer model can be used to fit triaxial density distributions.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does panel (c) of this figure illustrate?
choices: The radial distribution of mass within the cluster.
The variation in stellar density as a function of distance from the cluster center.
The change in the anisotropy of stellar velocities with distance from the cluster center.
The dependence of the distribution function on the radial action.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula represents the mass density profile of the Modified Plummer model. What is the key feature that distinguishes it from the traditional Plummer model?
choices: The presence of a core radius where the density remains constant.
A slower decline in density at intermediate radii compared to the traditional Plummer model.
An exponential cutoff in density at large radii.
The inclusion of a term to account for the presence of dark matter.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula introduces a method for flattening the spherical model. What is the effect of the parameter "qz"?
choices: It controls the amplitude of rotation within the cluster.
It determines the scale radius of the density profile.
It scales the vertical action, leading to a flattened density distribution.
It introduces a radial anisotropy in the velocity distribution.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the relationship between intrinsic ellipticity and rotation strength in globular clusters. What does the location of the data points below the isotropic rotator line indicate?
choices: The flattening in these clusters is primarily driven by rotation.
These clusters have a significant amount of dark matter.
The flattening in these clusters is more likely linked to anisotropy than to rotation.
These clusters are in the process of undergoing core collapse.
